sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: Given a signal $f(t) = 2\sin(4\pi t) + 3\cos(6\pi t)$, find its Fourier transform $F(\omega)$ and sketch the frequency spectrum.
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform $F(\omega)$ of the given signal $f(t) = 2\sin(4\pi t) + 3\cos(6\pi t)$, we can use the following Fourier transform formulas:

1. Fourier transform of $\sin(at)$: $\mathcal{F}\{\sin(at)\} = \dfrac{1}{2j}[\delta(\omega - a) - \delta(\omega + a)]$
2. Fourier transform of $\cos(at)$: $\mathcal{F}\{\cos(at)\} = \dfrac{1}{2}[\delta(\omega - a) + \delta(\omega + a)]$

Using these formulas, we can find the Fourier transform of each term in the given signal:

1. Fourier transform of $2\sin(4\pi t)$:
$\mathcal{F}\{2\sin(4\pi t)\} = 2 \cdot \dfrac{1}{2j}[\delta(\omega - 4\pi) - \delta(\omega + 4\pi)] = \dfrac{1}{j}[\delta(\omega - 4\pi) - \delta(\omega + 4\pi)]$

2. Fourier transform of $3\cos(6\pi t)$:
$\mathcal{F}\{3\cos(6\pi t)\} = 3 \cdot \dfrac{1}{2}[\delta(\omega - 6\pi) + \delta(\omega + 6\pi)] = \dfrac{3}{2}[\delta(\omega - 6\pi) + \delta(\omega + 6\pi)]$

Now, we can find the Fourier transform $F(\omega)$ of the given signal by adding the Fourier transforms of each term:

$F(\omega) = \dfrac{1}{j}[\delta(\omega - 4\pi) - \delta(\omega + 4\pi)] + \dfrac{3}{2}[\delta(\omega - 6\pi) + \delta(\omega + 6\pi)]$

To sketch the frequency spectrum, we can represent the Fourier transform as a sum of Dirac delta functions:

$F(\omega) = \dfrac{1}{j}\delta(\omega - 4\pi) - \dfrac{1}{j}\delta(\omega + 4\pi) + \dfrac{3}{2}\delta(\omega - 6\pi) + \dfrac{3}{2}\delta(\omega + 6\pi)$

The frequency spectrum will have four spikes at the following frequencies:

1. $\omega = -6\pi$ with amplitude $\dfrac{3}{2}$
2. $\omega = -4\pi$ with amplitude $-\dfrac{1}{j}$
3. $\omega = 4\pi$ with amplitude $\dfrac{1}{j}$
4. $\omega = 6\pi$ with amplitude $\dfrac{3}{2}$

To sketch the frequency spectrum, plot these four spikes on the frequency axis with their respective amplitudes.
